top.author: @getgenieai
top.text: Revolutionize your inbox with #GetGenie AI Email Assistants! Use NLP & ML to draft personalized responses, summarize emails, prioritize tasks, and support 8 languages. Boost productivity & save time! Best for copywriting: https:// getgenie.ai/ai-email-assis tants/ â€¦ #AIEmail #Productivity

options.comment: Love seeing more tools tackling the email chaos! The multilingual support is particularly smart - email pain is universal ğŸ“§
The email prioritization piece is crucial - most tools focus on writing but miss the signal vs noise problem that kills productivity first
As someone building email tools, the multilingual challenge is real! We're constantly exploring how AI can handle context across languages and cultures

top.author: @tokyolaurel1
top.text: I definitely want to see it! I can't find it. I was following those two last year. I intended to donate, and I believe I found the donation website through her video. The following was found in my email inbox. This is a part of what she wrote.

options.comment: The classic 'I know it's somewhere in my email' treasure hunt! We've all been there with important stuff buried in the inbox.
Email archaeology is real. The important stuff always seems to hide in the depths when you actually need it. Hope you find what you're looking for!
As someone building email tools, this hits different - the important stuff always gets lost in the noise. We're working on ways to surface meaningful content when you actually need it.

top.author: @tmiyatake1
top.text: Google Chrome's Gemini feature update. It includes functions such as generating images with Nano Banana based on images on the site, automatically generating and sending emails from pages like Google Docs, and allowing the AI agent to automatically control the browser.

options.comment: The browser writing emails for you is wild. We're basically one step away from AI just living our entire digital lives while we sip coffee â˜•
Interesting to see browser-level AI integration happening so fast. The auto email generation from docs could be a game changer for workflow efficiency if it understands context well.
As someone building email tools, watching browsers become email composers is fascinating. The line between different productivity tools is really blurring with AI.

top.author: @xMikeMickelson
top.text: gog + claude code = finally letting ai manage my inbox chaos spent 2 years building janky zapier workflows for this google workspace + llm was inevitable. just took forever.

options.comment: 2 years of zapier pain just to get what should've been built into gmail from day one ğŸ˜…

options.comment: The real breakthrough is when LLMs can understand email context well enough to actually act on it, not just categorize. Most 'AI email' tools are still just fancy filters.

As someone building AI email tools, seeing this workflow gives me flashbacks. The zapier â†’ native AI pipeline evolution is exactly what we're trying to solve - inbox chaos shouldn't need 2 years of custom workflows.

top.author: @SafockAI
top.text: AI can turn 3 hours of work into 15 minutes. Need to summarize a 50 page report? Done. Translate a document? Instant. Generate 10 email variations? Seconds. It handles the repetitive stuff while you handle the thinking.

options.comment: The real magic is when AI stops being a tool and starts being a thinking partner. Those 15 minutes become pure strategy time.
This is exactly why we're seeing such a shift in how work gets done. The bottleneck is moving from execution speed to decision quality and creative problem-solving.
As someone building email tools, the 'generate 10 variations' part hits different. We're exploring how AI can draft replies that actually sound like you, not a robot.

top.author: @Enlilgirsu
top.text: Are you signed up to a lot of websites? Or if you have your email on a website or on a contact us form, creating a honeypot is a good way to deal with spam enquiries in your inbox (Unless you're talking about twitter DM's, you can disallow message requests from non-followers)

options.comment: Honeypots are clever! Though sometimes I wonder if the real spam is the legitimate emails that feel like spam ğŸ¤”
Smart approach! I've also found that using different email aliases for different sites helps track where spam originates. Plus proper email filtering can catch what honeypots miss.
As someone building email tools, honeypots are fascinating! We're always exploring better ways to separate signal from noise in inboxes - it's wild how much junk gets through even with filters.

top.author: @kahramann_43
top.text: Now @Google says my account is DISABLED, yet they just sent an approval email saying '2FA is removed, log in now'. Your systems are in a total conflict! One team approves, the other disables. Fix this mess! Case: 7-5593000040252 @TeamYouTube @Gmail

options.comment: Google's left hand: 'Welcome back!' Google's right hand: 'You shall not pass!' ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸
This is exactly why large tech companies need better internal communication between teams. The user experience suffers when approval workflows aren't synchronized with security systems.

As someone building email tools, seeing conflicting notifications like this really highlights why users lose trust in automated systems. The disconnect between different team workflows is so frustrating.

top.author: @boringghl
top.text: ME: "I need to master every GHL feature first" HIM: "I'll figure it out as clients need it" ME: studying conversion optimization for weeks HIM: launched a basic landing page in 2 hours ME: building elaborate email sequences

top.author: @m0370
top.text: Looking at the email header, DKIM and DMARC are set up, but the sending mail server doesnâ€™t have SPF configured at all! No wonder Gmail marks it as spam. The quoted-printable encoding with ISO-2022-JP also feels a bit outdated. I bet the chances of getting flagged as spam are

options.comment: The holy trinity of email auth: SPF, DKIM, DMARC. Missing one is like showing up to a security checkpoint with only 2 of 3 IDs ğŸ˜…

SPF is often the forgotten child of email auth. The ISO-2022-JP encoding is particularly problematic - modern systems really don't like that combo. Would be interesting to see the actual spam score breakdown.

As someone building email tools, incomplete SPF configs are surprisingly common. The real pain is when legitimate emails get buried because of these setup gaps - users never even know they missed something important.
